article.headline: Notre Dame 82, DePaul 69
article.story: ROSEMONT, Ill. (AP) -- Chris Thomas has put up bigger numbers, but he might never have played a better game for Notre Dame. The junior guard scored 13 points, including five during a crucial run in the second half, to lead Notre Dame to a 82-69 win over DePaul on Sunday. Thomas added five assists and five rebounds to help the Irish (3-3) snap a three-game losing skid, but the stat line wasn't what impressed coach Mike Brey. "This may have been his best basketball game at Notre Dame as far as controlling the tempo, getting his teammates involved, making his teammates confident by getting them easy buckets and open looks," Brey said. "I think it was his best game." Thomas, who tied a career-low with seven shot attempts, hit a 3-pointer and had five points during a 10-2 run that gave Notre Dame a 65-55 lead. Thomas made four consecutive free throws down the stretch and had 11 of his 13 points in the second half. Thomas, Notre Dame's leading scorer at 19.6 points a game, was held scoreless until 10:54 into the game. He has scored in double figures in 26 straight games. "I just try to let the game come to me," Thomas said. "I think I took two shots in the first half and that doesn't bother me at all because we were up one. If that's what it takes for us to win, then I'll do that every day, every night." With Thomas creating shots instead of taking them, it was up to Jordan Cornette and Colin Falls to play bigger roles on offense. Cornette responded with a career-high 17 points and Falls had 12 points, also a career high. Brey shook up his lineup before the game, hoping to avoid the school's first four-game losing streak since 1999-2000. He put Falls in the starting lineup and benched Cornette, who had started all five games this season. The moves worked. Falls, a standout prep star from the Chicago area who was making his second career start, shot 4-for-8 from 3-point range. Cornette, averaging just 5.6 points entering the game, shot 6-of-10 from the field and had seven rebounds. "I told them when we started to talk about these changes that this is not a demotion. But we're not in a very good atmosphere right now," Brey said. "I don't think any of them would have disagreed with me." The result was one of the best shooting games of the season for the Irish, who finished at 51 percent. Notre Dame entered the game shooting 39 percent from the field. The setback spoiled an emotional halftime ceremony honoring former DePaul coach and Chicago-legend Ray Meyer. DePaul named its basketball court after Meyer and his late wife Marge. Meyer is the 11th winningest coach in NCAA history and guided the Blue Demons to a 724-354 record during his 42 years as coach, from 1942-84. Even with a boost from the presence of Meyer, DePaul didn't have enough over the final 10 minutes to pull out the win. The Blue Demons cut the deficit to seven when Cornette made consecutive 3-pointers to push the lead back to double figures with 4:21 left. Delonte Holland led DePaul (5-2) with 23 points, and Andre Brown had 22 points and 11 rebounds. Notre Dame trailed most of the opening period, but took a 39-38 lead at the break on a reverse layup by Cornette. After a 3-pointer by Falls, DePaul went on a 13-2 run to take an early eight-point lead. Brown opened the run with a short jumper and capped it with a spinning move down low. DePaul finished with a 42-33 rebounding advantage, but shot just 39 percent in the second half. "I just feel like we let it slip away from us. Our defense really went sour in the second half," Holland said.
